title: Spyware Targeting Journalists and Activists in Italy Raises Privacy Concerns
summary:
- Italian journalist Francesco Cancellato was notified of being targeted by Israeli spyware from [Paragon Solutions](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=paragon%20solutions).
- Cancellato is notable for revealing fascist activities in Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's far-right party.
- WhatsApp reported that 90 journalists and others were targeted, with spyware activity discovered in December.
- Paragon's spyware, Graphite, can infect devices via group chats and PDFs without user interaction.
- Cancellato views the incident as a severe privacy violation with no known investigations against him.

- Human rights activist David Yambio also had his phone targeted by spyware, confirmed by Apple.
- Yambio is critical of Italy's migrant pact with Libya and contributes to [ICC](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=icc) evidence collection.
- On November 13, Yambio was notified of a mercenary spyware attack potentially aimed at him.
- Citizen Lab is investigating spyware targeting activists and journalists in Italy.
- Yambio's situation raises political and safety concerns regarding ICC witnesses.

sources.title: Italian investigative journalist targeted on WhatsApp by Israeli spyware
Campaigner for migrants in Libya says his phone was targeted in spyware attack

title: Microsoft adjusts pricing to address EU concerns: sources
summary:
- Microsoft is adjusting pricing to address EU antitrust scrutiny by increasing the price gap between its Office suite with Teams and the standalone Office product.
- The decision follows complaints from competitors about Microsoft's bundling practices, particularly from Slack in 2020.
- In 2023, Microsoft unbundled Teams from Office, allowing users to buy Office at a price 2 euros less than the bundled version, with standalone Teams priced at 5 euros per month.
- The goal of the new pricing is to enhance competitiveness of rival products in the market.

title: Tech giants launch initiative to boost child online safety

- ROOST has secured over US$27 million in funding to develop free, open-source tools that combat online child exploitation.
- The tools will identify and report child sexual abuse material, enhancing safety measures online.
- Reports of suspected child exploitation have risen, with the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children noting a 12% increase from 2022 to 2023.
- Reports involving Roblox surged by 348%, while incidents linked to Discord doubled during the same period.

title: Backdoor Infecting VPNs Uses Stealthy Magic Packets for Attacks
summary:
- Ivanti VPN networks are under active attack exploiting the critical vulnerability [CVE-2025-0282](https://arstechnica.com/security/2025/01/ivanti-vpn-users-are-getting-hacked-by-actors-exploiting-a-critical-vulnerability/).
- This vulnerability allows complete control over network-connected devices with no authentication required.
- A security patch was released, upgrading Connect Secure devices to version 22.7R2.5.
- Attackers exploit this vulnerability to install new malware packages, DRYHOOK and PHASEJAM.
- PHASEJAM creates a web shell for remote access and simulates the upgrade process to deceive administrators.
- SPAWNANT malware is also used to disable Ivanti's integrity checker for device files.
- Researchers revealed a new backdoor, J-Magic, affecting enterprise VPNs using Juniper's Junos OS.
- The backdoor remains dormant until it receives a 'magic packet', which includes a challenge encrypted with an RSA key.
- J-Magic only exists in memory, making it harder to detect and has been identified in 36 organizations' networks.

sources.title: Ongoing attacks on Ivanti VPNs install a ton of sneaky, well-written malware
Backdoor infecting VPNs used ‚Äúmagic packets‚Äù for stealth and security

title: Apple and Google take down malicious mobile apps from their app stores
summary:
- Apple and Google removed 20 malicious apps from their app stores after Kaspersky's report.
- The malware, called SparkCat, has been active since March 2024 and was found in a food delivery app and 19 other unrelated apps.
- SparkCat was downloaded over 242,000 times and could capture recovery phrases for cryptocurrency wallets, enabling theft of funds.
- Google confirmed that it has banned the developers of the affected apps and protected Android users with Google Play Protect.
- The compromised apps were also found on non-official app stores despite being pulled from official platforms.

title: Is AI making us dumb?
summary:
- Researchers from Microsoft and Carnegie Mellon University published a study on the effects of generative AI on critical thinking skills.
- The paper warns that overreliance on AI may deteriorate cognitive faculties by shifting focus from higher-order thinking to verification of AI outputs.
- In a study of 319 participants using AI weekly, 36% reported utilizing critical thinking skills to counter AI shortcomings.
- Participants often verified AI outputs with external sources, undermining the AI's utility.
- Confident users of AI tended to use less critical thinking than those confident in their own abilities.
- Researchers suggest that while AI tools don't make users dumber, they can weaken problem-solving capacity if abused.

sources.title: Is AI making us dumb?

title: Global Police Operation Targets 8base Ransomware Gang Amid Decreasing Ransomware Payments in 2024
summary:
- Ransomware payments fell by over a third to $813 million in 2024, down from $1.25 billion in 2023.
- Major incidents included attacks on NHS trusts and Krispy Kreme.
- Decline attributed to victims refusing to pay and intensified law enforcement actions against cybercriminals.
- Total payments for 2024 are lower than previous years, below 2020's $999 million and 2019's $1.1 billion.
- Expert Jacqueline Burns Koven suggests this indicates averted 'ransomware apocalypse' due to effective collaboration and victim resistance.
- Despite the decline, ransomware attacks are still frequent, with rising demands from cyber gangs.
- UK ministers are considering a ban on ransomware payments by public entities, proposing mandatory reporting of such payments.
- Payments dropped more than 35% in 2024, with hacker demands 53% higher than actual payments in the second half of the year.
- Law enforcement efforts successfully targeted major ransomware groups like BlackCat and Lockbit in 2024, contributing to payment declines.
- International law enforcement agencies seized the 8base ransomware gang's dark web leak site.
- The operation involved agencies from Europe, Japan, U.S., and U.K., coordinated by the Bavarian State Criminal Police.
- 8base is linked to RansomHouse and employs double-extortion tactics, demanding ransom while threatening to expose sensitive info.
- The group targeted multiple sectors, especially healthcare, and was linked to a cyberattack on the United Nations Development Programme.
- The takedown message was confirmed by the U.K.'s National Crime Agency.

sources.title: Global ransomware payments plunge by a third amid crackdown
Ransomware payments dropped in 2024 as victims refused to pay hackers

title: UK Government Orders Apple to Create iCloud Backdoor for Encrypted Data Access
summary:
- The UK government secretly ordered Apple to create a backdoor for accessing users' encrypted iCloud data.
- The demand was made in January under the UK's Investigatory Powers Act 2016, requesting blanket access to all encrypted files.
- Apple may stop offering its encrypted cloud storage, Advanced Data Protection, to UK users due to this demand.
- A technical capability notice under the Investigatory Powers Act requires Apple to assist law enforcement globally.
- Apple's Advanced Data Protection service utilizes end-to-end encryption, meaning only account holders can decrypt files.
- Apple has stated it would refuse to build a backdoor and withdraw security features from the UK market instead.
- The UK government‚Äôs demand may lead to conflicts with EU data-sharing agreements.
- This move is part of a broader effort to enhance national security and public safety.
- Concerns about privacy and data security among users and technology experts are being raised in response to the demand.
- Critics fear this sets a dangerous precedent, potentially weakening security for Apple users worldwide and eroding civil liberties.

title: PowerSchool Data Breach Affects 16,000 Students in the UK and Exposes Sensitive Information
summary:
- A significant data breach at PowerSchool compromised sensitive personal data for millions across North America.
- Exposed information includes Social Security numbers, medical data, and detailed student records.
- The Toronto District School Board confirmed data from all students from 1985 to 2024 was affected.
- Approximately 62 million students and 9.5 million teachers are estimated to be impacted by the December 2024 breach.
- Attackers accessed data via a compromised account lacking multi-factor authentication.
- Key institutions affected include the Toronto District School Board and Calgary Board of Education.
- Awareness of the breach began on December 28, 2024; notifications to affected individuals started on January 29, 2025.
- The exact number of affected students or specific data accessed by PowerSchool remains unconfirmed and under investigation.
- The identity of the hackers and findings from CrowdStrike‚Äôs investigation have yet to be disclosed.
- Grubhub also reported a breach linked to unauthorized access from a third-party provider, affecting customer and driver details.
- Personal details compromised at Grubhub included names and email addresses; Social Security numbers were not affected.
- PowerSchool confirmed the data breach affecting 16,000 students in the UK involved hackers accessing data via compromised customer support credentials.
- Affected data includes contact info, dates of birth, and limited medical data; four UK schools were impacted but not named.
- PowerSchool has not reported the breach to the UK Information Commissioner‚Äôs Office yet.

title: EU Details AI Act Scope and Bans Unacceptable Risk AI Systems
summary:

- Organizations must comply by February 2, with enforcement details in August 2025.

- Guidelines are illustrative, not legally binding; enforcement handled by regulators.
- Adoption of guidelines awaits translation into EU languages.
- Future compliance deadlines are expected; Member States have until August 2 to appoint oversight bodies.
- The European Union has published guidance on defining AI systems under the AI Act.
- The risk-based framework regulating AI applications came into force last summer, with the first compliance deadline recently occurring.
- AI developers must determine if their software falls within the act‚Äôs scope to avoid fines of up to 7% of global annual turnover for breaches.
- The 13-page guidelines from the Commission are non-binding and subject to updates as the AI field evolves.
- The EU warns that there won't be exhaustive lists defining systems that fall within or outside the AI system definition.

title: US Immigration is Gaming Google to Create a Mirage of Mass Deportations

title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid
summary:
- Researchers discovered that renewable energy facilities in Central Europe use unencrypted radio signals for controlling power grid input and output.
- The system allows for the control of approximately 60 GW of energy, including both generation and load management.
- An optimally crafted series of messages could theoretically disable the entire European power grid, a potential risk they highlighted at the 38th Chaos Communication Congress.
- The communication protocol utilized is called Radio Ripple Control, which is based on an older protocol dating back to the early 1900s.
- No encryption is applied to the signals, allowing unauthorized users to intercept and manipulate them.

sources.title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid

title: AI Model s1 Competes with OpenAI‚Äôs o1 at a Fraction of the Cost
summary:
- AI researchers from Stanford and the University of Washington trained the AI reasoning model **s1** for under **$50** in cloud compute credits.
- **s1** performs comparably to advanced models like OpenAI's **o1** and DeepSeek's **R1**, particularly excelling in math and coding tests.
- The model, distilled from Google's Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking Experimental, is available on [GitHub](https://github.com/simplescaling/s1).
- It was trained on a dataset of **1,000** curated questions using cost-effective supervised fine-tuning (SFT).
- **s1** achieved strong benchmark results after a training time of less than **30 minutes** on **16 Nvidia H100 GPUs**, with total compute costs around **$20**.
- Major companies like Meta, Google, and Microsoft are projected to invest hundreds of billions in AI infrastructure by **2025**.
- The model was introduced on **Feb. 2** and reached state-of-the-art performance at a low training cost of **$6**.
- Training took **26 minutes** and utilized a distilled dataset from **Qwen2.5**.
- Innovations like **s1** promote experimentation with limited resources, raising discussions on ethical issues regarding **distilling** datasets from existing AI models.

sources.title: Researchers created an open rival to OpenAI‚Äôs o1 ‚Äòreasoning‚Äô model for under $50

- This study aims to create accessible reasoning benchmarks that don‚Äôt require advanced knowledge, promoting better understanding of AI capabilities.

title: Why IQ is a poor test for AI
summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman noted AI's rapid improvement in IQ over recent years, suggesting an increase of about one standard deviation of IQ annually.
- Experts criticize IQ as a misleading measure for AI capabilities, emphasizing that IQ tests are based on human intelligence criteria, which do not apply to AI.
- Sandra Wachter points out the biases and limitations of IQ tests, arguing they oversimplify human intelligence and can lead to incorrect assumptions about AI's capabilities.
- AI potentially has an advantage on IQ tests due to its ability to process and memorize vast amounts of information from training data.
- Experts call for the development of better testing measures for AI that account for its unique problem-solving approaches, as current IQ tests are designed primarily for human evaluation.

sources.title: Why IQ is a poor test for AI

title: Deepfake videos are getting shockingly good

- Deepfakes have been part of spreading misinformation and financial fraud, causing substantial losses in recent years.
- An open letter from the AI community calls for strict regulations on deepfakes; some states are enacting laws against AI impersonation.

title: EFishery Confirms Fraud Allegations and Restructuring by FTI Consulting
summary:

- Six others were aware of inflated figures but did not report them to the board.
- Fraud involved bonuses based on inflated financials totaling $1.3 million and schemes to mislead auditors.
- FTI Consulting is conducting the ongoing investigation and has not yet interviewed all individuals mentioned in the report.
- The board confirmed misconduct allegations, and FTI Consulting will take over as acting management after receiving shareholder approval.
- The company plans a thorough business review; the number of layoffs is currently unclear.

title: Meta says it may stop development of AI systems it deems too risky

‚Ä¢ Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg aims to make artificial general intelligence (AGI) open in the future.
‚Ä¢ Meta's new Frontier AI Framework categorizes AI systems as "high-risk" or "critical-risk" based on their potential for harm.
‚Ä¢ High-risk systems may assist in attacks but are less reliable, while critical-risk systems could result in catastrophic outcomes.
‚Ä¢ Meta's classification relies on input from researchers rather than empirical tests, due to lack of robust evaluation metrics.
‚Ä¢ If a system is deemed high-risk, internal access will be limited; critical-risk systems will halt development until mitigations are in place.
‚Ä¢ Meta's approach contrasts with companies like OpenAI, as it has previously released AI models openly, leading to both successes and security concerns.

sources.title: Meta says it may stop development of AI systems it deems too risky

title: No, DeepSeek isn‚Äôt uncensored if you run it locally
summary:

title: OpenAI Unveils New AI Tool for Efficient Online Research
summary:
- OpenAI introduced a new tool named ‚ÄúDeep Research‚Äù for enhancing online research efficiency.
- The tool scans text, images, PDFs, and uploaded files to generate detailed reports based on user prompts.
- OpenAI claims Deep Research can complete tasks that usually take hours in just minutes.
- It is exclusively available to ChatGPT Pro subscribers at a cost of US$200 per month.
- Deep Research can analyze and summarize information from various sources, providing citations and a cohesive report.
- It can complete tasks in 5 to 30 minutes, significantly faster than a human researcher.
- Limitations include potential hallucinations and difficulty distinguishing rumors from authoritative information.

title: Meta's Plans to Appeal to Gen Z with Ads and a Return to OG Facebook
summary:
- Meta Platforms launched ads on Threads in the US and Japan.
- Brands participating in the initiative were selected; the announcement was made by Adam Mosseri on January 24.
- This marks the beginning of monetization for Threads, launched in 2023.
- Effectiveness of the test will be evaluated before a wider rollout.
- The goal is for ads to be engaging like organic content.
- As of December 2024, Threads had 300 million monthly users and over 100 million daily active users.
- Zuckerberg announced plans for a "return to OG Facebook" by 2025 during the Q4 earnings call.
- Specific changes are not disclosed; the focus is on restoring cultural influence and attracting younger users.
- Changes could affect short-term revenues, anticipated rollout in six months.
- Gen Z's declining interest presents a challenge for Facebook.
- Past attempts to engage younger audiences, like Facebook Campus and the Gen Z redesign, have been unsuccessful.
- Recent studies indicate only 33% of U.S. teens currently use Facebook, down from 71% a decade ago.
- Zuckerberg's vision for "OG Facebook" remains vague, possibly referencing its earlier versions or nostalgic elements.

title: Korean automaker faces trademark battle in Turkey

title: 161 years ago, a New Zealand sheep farmer predicted AI doom
summary:

- He emphasized the relationship between the evolution of machines and Darwinian principles, expressing admiration for Darwin's work.

title: DeepSeek's AI Innovations Raise Concerns about U.S. Competitiveness
summary:

- DeepSeek‚Äôs app became the most downloaded free app in the US and UK stores, facing initial app store challenges in Italy over data privacy.

title: Massive Data Breach Affects Over 190 Million Americans and 1 Million Patients at US Nonprofit Healthcare Provider
summary:
- UnitedHealth confirmed a ransomware attack on Change Healthcare impacted around **190 million people** in the U.S., marking it as the largest medical data breach in history.
- The attack occurred in February 2024, leading to significant healthcare system disruptions and compromising personal and medical data.
- The **ALPHV ransomware gang** used stolen credentials to facilitate the breach, which lacked multi-factor authentication.
- Key dates include:
 - February 21, 2024: Network shut down initiated to combat cyber intruders.
 - February 29, 2024: ALPHV/BlackCat ransomware gang identified.
 - March 3-5, 2024: UnitedHealth paid $22 million ransom without receiving the stolen data back.
 - June 20, 2024: Affected individuals notified as required by HIPAA.
 - July 29, 2024: Confirmation letters sent to individuals about the compromised data.
- Community Health Center reported sensitive data theft of over 1 million patients, detected on January 2, 2025, with unauthorized access starting on October 14, 2024.
- A comprehensive glossary of cybersecurity terms created by TechCrunch, which will be regularly updated and invites user feedback.

title: Former OpenAI Researcher Raises Alarm About Risks of AI Development

- He notes that no research lab currently has a solution for AI alignment, raising alarms about the industry‚Äôs speed compromising safety regulations.
- Steven Adler resigned due to concerns about the rapid pace of AI development, having worked at OpenAI since March 2022.
- He is worried that AGI could exceed human intelligence and warned that the global race to achieve AGI is a 'very risky gamble'.
- Adler emphasized that the urgency may compromise vital safety measures needed for AI alignment with human values.
- Despite assurances from OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Adler hopes for stronger safety regulations within AI labs.
- He mentioned increasing competition, particularly with the launch of DeepSeek by a Chinese startup, and stressed the need for collaboration to mitigate AI risks.

title: Majority of U.S. Teens Have Lost Trust in Big Tech Amid Apple Intelligence Concerns
summary:
- Apple released software updates including iOS 18.3, opting users into [Apple Intelligence](https://techcrunch.com/tag/apple-intelligence/).
- Users may wish to disable AI features due to concerns about the [environment](https://www.unep.org/news-and-stories/story/ai-has-environmental-problem-heres-what-world-can-do-about#:~:text=But%20when%20it%20comes%20to,becoming%20scarce%20in%20many%20places.) or [political views](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/13/sam-altman-and-jeff-bezos-are-the-latest-billionaires-to-donate-1m-to-trump-fund/).
- Instructions to disable Apple Intelligence: Go to *Settings* on iOS or *System Settings* on Mac, tap or click on *Apple Intelligence*, and toggle it off.
- On iOS, locate *Apple Intelligence & Siri*, toggle the switch, and consider disabling Siri for privacy. 
- Apple claims its AI features prioritize privacy using a system called [Private Cloud Computer](https://techcrunch.com/2024/10/24/apple-will-pay-security-researchers-up-to-1-million-to-hack-its-private-ai-cloud/).
- A report by [Common Sense Media](https://www.commonsensemedia.org/) shows American teens have increasingly lost trust in major tech companies.
- A survey of over 1,000 teens reveals that 64% believe these companies neglect their mental health.
- Distrust is heightened due to scenarios like the [NSA's mass data collection](https://techcrunch.com/2013/06/06/report-nsa-collects-data-directly-from-servers-of-google-apple-microsoft-facebook-and-more/) and the Cambridge Analytica scandal.
- More than half of teens question the ethical decision-making of tech companies and their ability to protect personal data.
- 74% of teens support stronger privacy protections and transparency in AI, while 61% think content creators should be paid for data used by AI.

sources.title: How to switch off Apple Intelligence on your iPhone, iPad, and Mac

title: International AI Safety Report Highlights Job Risks, Climate Concerns, and Cybersecurity Threats

- AI systems now capable of generating harmful instructions autonomously.
- The report notes increased risks from both open-source and closed-source AI models, emphasizing the need for regulatory intervention.
- It warns of profound job impacts due to capable AI agents, with potential for new jobs but also significant job losses in advanced economies.
- AI's energy consumption contributes to 1% of greenhouse gas emissions, raising environmental concerns.
- Concerns over loss of control of powerful AI systems are noted, with varying opinions on the likelihood of negative outcomes.
- AI models could create advanced bioweapons, but there are uncertainties about their use by untrained individuals.
- Cybersecurity threats from AI include autonomous bots finding software vulnerabilities.
- The report discusses the malicious use of deepfakes, noting a lack of data to fully measure the impact.

title: White House Evaluates National Security Risks of DeepSeek AI and Its Disruptive Chatbot
summary:

title: Apple Chips Vulnerabilities Allow Data Leak from Browsers
summary:
- Apple-designed chips in Macs, iPhones, and iPads have two vulnerabilities leaking sensitive data from Chrome and Safari.  
- Vulnerabilities enable side channel attacks via speculative execution optimizations, affecting A- and M-series chip sets.  
- The more significant attack, FLOP, can read sensitive data like location history and credit card info from targeted sites.  
- SLAP is limited to reading adjacent strings from another webpage.  
- Affected devices include recent Mac laptops, desktops, iPads, and iPhones since 2021.  
- Researchers suggest potential mitigations and await patch plans from Apple, although Apple claims there's no immediate risk.

title: Tech billionaires lost almost $100bn in stock market selloff sparked by DeepSeek + Nvidia leads market value, surpasses Apple
summary:
- Nvidia became the world's most valuable publicly traded company on Jan. 23, surpassing Apple in market value.
- On Jan. 23, Nvidia's market capitalization reached approximately US$3.45 trillion, with a 2% increase in shares.
- In 2024, Nvidia's stock increased by 171%, and in 2023 by nearly 239%, fueled by high demand for AI-focused chips.
- Apple's shares fell by 3%, leading to a market valuation of US$3.35 trillion, and its stock is down 11% in 2025 after gaining 30% in 2024.
- Apple lacks Nvidia's extensive exposure to the rapidly growing AI sector despite adding AI features to its products.
- DeepSeek's AI challenge caused a $600bn loss in Nvidia's market value, leading to a 3% drop in Nasdaq.
- Nvidia's stock plunge resulted in CEO Jensen Huang losing $20.7bn, dropping from 10th to 17th in global wealth rankings.
- Oracle's Larry Ellison lost $27.6bn, falling from third to fifth wealthiest.
- Total losses among tech billionaires reached $94bn, contributing to the $108bn loss reported.
- Upcoming earnings reports from Meta, Microsoft, Tesla, and Apple may address AI spending concerns.
- Analysts suggest selloff may be an overreaction; demand for top AI hardware is expected to persist.

title: Cyberattacks Impact Millions: Ascension and ENGlobal Breaches
summary:
- Ascension experienced a cyberattack affecting 5.6 million individuals' sensitive data.
- The attack was linked to a notorious ransomware gang and disrupted operations in May.
- Affected data included names, medical information, payment details, insurance information, and government identification numbers.
- Most services were restored by mid-June after staff transitioned to manual processes due to the attack.
- A filing in December confirmed the scale of the breach and types of data compromised.

- U.S. engineering firm ENGlobal reported that hackers accessed 'sensitive personal information' during a November 2024 cyberattack.
- The attack led to the encryption of some data files, indicating a potential ransomware incident.
- Business applications, including financial reporting systems, were offline for approximately six weeks.
- The company has not disclosed the number of individuals affected or the types of data accessed but plans to notify those impacted.
- ENGlobal stated its operations are now 'fully restored' and believes the hackers no longer have access to its IT systems.
